Review Important roles of graphene edges in carbon-based energy storage devices Yoong Ahm Kim a * Takuya Hayashi a Jin Hee Kim a Morinobu Endo b a Faculty of Engineering, Shinshu University, 4–17–1 Wakasato, Nagano 380–8553, Japan Faculty of Engineering Shinshu University 4–17–1 Wakasato Nagano 380–8553 Japan b Research Center for Exotic Nanocarbons (JST), Shinshu University, 4–17–1 Wakasato, Nagano 380–8553, Japan Research Center for Exotic Nanocarbons (JST) Shinshu University 4–17–1 Wakasato Nagano 380–8553 Japan * Corresponding author. Tel: +81-26-269-5212; Fax: +81-26-269-5212 Nanostructured carbon materials, including carbon nanotubes, graphene and nanoporous carbon, show promise for expanding renewable energy. In particular, the configuration and electronic properties of graphene edges in relation with their electrochemical activity have become a major issue in carbon-based energy storage devices. Here, we review recent results concerning the important roles of graphene edges as the gateway for lithium ion intercalation in the anode of lithium-ion batteries, as promoters of high capacitance in carbon-based supercapacitors, and as anchoring sites for Pt nanoparticles in fuel cells. We envisage that the controlled synthesis of a specific, clean, and stable edge configuration could be achieved to maximize the electrochemical performance of nanostructured carbon-based energy storage devices. Key words carbon nanotube graphene edge lithium ion battery supercapacitor fuel cell 1. Introduction With the recent boom in nanotechnology, nanoengineered carbon materials, including carbon nanotubes and graphene, have attracted considerable attention because of their high thermal conductivity, excellent mechanical strength, high electron mobility, and unique electronic properties [1–5]. Intrinsically, sp 2-based carbon materials exhibit two different types of surfaces: (1) the homogeneous and smooth hexagonal plane known as the basal plane and (2) the edges, which are decorated with mostly oxygen-containing functional groups (Figure 1a ). The edge and basal planes differ greatly in their physicochemical properties, which determine their electrochemical activity. The edge as opposed to the basal plane is generally considered to make the predominant contribution to the electronic and chemical properties of a carbon material. Moreover, there are two types of edges (i.e., zigzag and armchair), as shown in Figure 1 (b). Thus, the electronic properties of an edge largely depend on edge configuration. The armchair edge is energetically more stable than the zigzag edge. Theoretically, it has also been found that graphene has a nonbonding π-electron state that is localized in zigzag edges and enhances the local density of states near the Fermi energy [6]. Therefore, enormous effort has been put into understanding the effect that edges have on the optical, chemical, magnetic, electrical, and electronic properties of graphene as well as into fabricating clean edges and characterizing a specific edge [7–10]. One example is graphene nanoribbons, which are dominated by edge effects and are known to behave as a quasi-one-dimensional material with a band gap [11,12]. From the viewpoint of carbon-based energy storage devices, edges are known to play a major role in the electrochemical performance of a variety of carbon materials. For example, in the anode of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), the edges of layered carbon (i.e., three-dimensionally stacked graphite) are considered to be the gateway by which lithium ions intercalate between graphite layers [13,14]. In carbon-based electrode materials used in supercapacitors, the edge is known to show capacitance several times greater than that of the basal plane [15–18]. Thus, the systematic understanding of the nature of edges, through both theory and experiment, is critical to improve the electrochemical performance of a variety of carbon materials in energy storage devices. Within this context, the review focuses on significant recent results on the controlled nanoscale texture of carbon materials, especially the relationship between the configuration and electronic properties of graphene edges and their contributions to the electrochemical performance of energy storage devices. The next three sections deal with how edges affect the intercalation/deintercalation behavior of lithium ions (Li+), and how edge-controlled carbon nanotubes are effective in improving the anode performance of lithium-ion batteries. The fifth section describes the accelerating effect of substitutional boron atoms on loop formation between adjacent edges in terms of their thermal stability. The sixth section covers how microporous carbon materials with large numbers of edges are effective in achieving high-performance carbon-based super-capacitance, particularly with a high volumetric capacitance. Finally, the utilization of nanoengineered carbon materials as supports for catalyst particles in fuel cells will be described with emphasis on how edges act as efficient anchoring sites. 2. In-situ Raman study on intercalation of lithium ions in graphite With the development of advanced lithium-ion batteries in the 1990s, they have become widespread in daily life [19,20]. Carbon structures are now widely used as anode materials in order to overcome safety problems related to secondary lithium-ion batteries. It is noteworthy that Li+ are able to intercalate between layers of graphene by way of the edges. Figure 2(a) shows the various stage structures of Li-graphite intercalation compounds. The lithium electrochemically inserted between graphene layers is thought to exist as ions but shielding effects caused by stored electrons on the layers may prohibit perceiving the existence of the newly inserted lithium ions. Another possibility is stacking faults in the graphene layers. As a reference carbon material, synthetic graphite (ca. 45 µm) electrodes were observed by in-situ Raman spectroscopy [21]. In this case, Li+ intercalation mainly occurred below 0.25 V and three distinct plateaus at 0.18, 0.08, and 0.05 V were observed. The upshift in the G band at 0.15 V (Figure 2b) is attributed to the random intercalation of Li+ in a highly dilute state. The separation of the G-bands at 0.075 V indicates a stage structure (graphite intercalation compounds); G-bands located at 1600 and 1580 cm−1 can respectively be assigned to the graphene layers without and with Li+ ion intercalates (bounding layer mode) [22]. By observing color changes in the observation aperture of the coin cell, the intercalation status can be clearly seen. Specifically, the appearance of a light yellow color at 0.05 V provides strong evidence of a stage 2 phase (LiC12). Upon full Li+ intercalation, we observed a more intense yellow color, corresponding to LiC6. 3. Application of carbon nanotubes as conductive filler to anode and cathode of lithium ion batteries At present, portable electronic devices and hybrid electric vehicles have increasingly strict requirements for safe and high-performance lithium-ion batteries. Therefore, new types of nanostructured electrode materials or fillers, including carbon nanotubes, have been examined for improving the electrochemical performance of lithium-ion batteries (e.g., large capacity, high rate capability and long life cycle), as well as for developing new end-use products (e.g., cosmetics) [23–28]. In 2012, 200 ton of highly pure crystalline carbon nanotubes were incorporated as effective fillers in anode and cathode materials because their mechanical and electrical properties are believed to play an important role in extending the life cycle of commercial lithium-ion batteries [29,30]. However, carbon nanotubes consist of cylindrical walls that are comparable to low-reactivity basal planes and tube ends that are similar to electrochemically active edges. Thus, the electrochemical activity on the outer surface of pristine nanotubes is not uniform and thus the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) layer formed on the edges is believed to be denser and stronger than that formed on the basal plane according to the Peled's work [31]. Irregular SEI films are not favorable for cyclic performance. Thus, as-synthesized tubes are thermally treated at high temperature under argon in order to improve their electrical conductivity and mechanical strength via the removal of entrapped metallic impurities below 30 ppm and to convert the electrochemically active edge sites to inactive tube ends with loop formation (Figure 3 ) [32–35]. In this way, highly uniform electrochemical reactivity on the surface of carbon nanotubes is achieved utilizing high-temperature thermal treatment. These highly crystalline and electrochemically inactive carbon nanotubes will aid in the construction of anodes and cathodes which feature (a) higher electrical conductivity, (b) greater structural integrity, (c) higher thermal conductivity, (d) higher density, and (e) a shortened electrolyte absorption time. These characteristics will allow for lithium-ion batteries with high rate capability, good cycling characteristics, improved cell safety, and enhanced productivity (Figure 4 ). Thus, the utilization of carbon nanotubes as conductive fillers in preparing safe and high-rate lithium-ion batteries for hybrid electric vehicles will surely increase. 4. Crystalline carbon nanotubes with active edges Lithium-ion batteries for hybrid electric vehicles must sustain high charge-discharge rates (or rate capability). However, it is well known that the slow solid-state diffusion of Li+ limits the intercalation capacity of graphite. Thus, the utilization of nanocarbon materials with large accessible surface areas is one option to satisfy the need for a high rate of Li+ intercalation/deintercalation [23–28]. Unfortunately, it is very difficult to prepare nanocarbon materials with three-dimensional stacking as well as a high fraction of active sites by pulverizing graphite into nanoparticles or by thermally treating nanoparticles at high temperatures. The former case introduces structural perturbation whereas the latter results in the substantial loss of active edge sites. Notably, charge transfer takes place along the entire surface of graphite, but Li+ intercalation occurs at only graphite edge sites. Thus, short tubes formed by ball milling carbon nanotubes containing a faceted cross-sectional morphology were shown to be an effective anode material for sustaining the rate of intercalation/deintercalation. By cutting long crystalline carbon nanotubes with faceted cross-sectional morphologies into short tubes (Figure 5a and b ), the relative number of edges with respect to basal planes was increased with milling time. The tube ends exhibited linear edge sites (Figure 5c) and milling time for up to 3 h did not cause the crystallinity of tubes to deteriorate (Figure 5d). Short tubes prepared by 3 h of ball milling showed the highest discharge capacity as well as a high rate capability. Cutting tubes after thermal annealing is vital because the end planes in the shortened tubes can be transformed into stable loops via high-temperature thermal treatment. In addition, the judicious selection of a cutting method (ball milling rather than the high-speed milling) is critical to fully expose electrochemical edges without deformation. 5. Boron accelerates the loop formation from adjacent loops The carbon nanostructures contain a large number of active edge sites (dangling bonds) that are predominantly present on accessible surfaces; consequently, these active edge sites determine the physical, chemical and electronic properties of the materials [36–40]. The active end planes provide sites for the decomposition of solvated lithium and subsequent SEI formation [41], resulting in noticeable hysteresis and irreversibility [42]. In order to fully and reproducibly exploit the intrinsic properties of the carbon nanostructures, a method for controlling their surface characteristics and texture is essential. To date, two methods for modifying edges have been reported: (1) the selective formation of zigzag and armchair edges using Joule heating [43] and (2) the formation of a single loop and multi-loops between adjacent active edges by high-temperature thermal treatment in argon [44–48]. Here, boron atoms (B) was suggested as a surface modifier of carbon nanofibers [49] because of its high ability to substitute into the hexagonal carbon network [50,51]. Thus, catalytically grown platelet-type carbon nanofibers were selected as a starting material [37] since relatively crystalline graphene layers are stacked regularly along the length direction of the carbon nanofiber, and the accessible surface area is covered with active edges. In order to evaluate the effectiveness of B as a stabilizing agent for open edges (dangling bonds), carbon nanofibers were thermally treated in the presence of elemental B at various temperatures using a graphite furnace. Carbon nanofibers are in the form of short rods (Figure 6a ) and have semi-rectangular cross-sectional morphology (inset in Figure 6a) [49]. Moreover, relatively crystalline graphene layers are stacked regularly along the length direction of the carbon nanofiber (Figure 6b) [49], the accessible surface area of which is fully covered with chemically active end planes. When an undoped sample was thermally treated in argon at 2200 and 2500 °C, the active edges were structurally converted to energetically stable multi-loops (Figure 6c and 6d) [49]. For the undoped sample, multi-loop formation was not observed at 1900 °C. In contrast, we clearly observed formation of multi-loops in a B-doped sample treated at 1900 °C (Figure 6e). In addition, the B-doped sample treated at 2500 °C (Figure 6f) had a higher number of multi-loops than that the corresponding undoped sample (Figure 6d) [49]. Therefore, it is assumed that B atoms play an important role in loop formation, leading to changes in the surface morphology of carbon nanofibers during high-temperature thermal treatment. In order to evaluate the physical changes in the B-doped carbon nanofibers, their electrical resistivity in the bulk state was measured using a four-point probe method (Figure 7a ) [49]. After pouring a specific amount of the carbon nanofibers into the sample holder, the volumetric resistivity was measured at a nanotube mass density of 1.23 g/cm3. Generally, B-doped samples exhibited improved electrical conductivity compared with undoped samples. It is noteworthy that the electrical resistivity in the bulk state is determined by both the contact resistivity between fibres and the intrinsic resistivity of individual fibres. Therefore, we measured the electrical resistivity of a freestanding individual nanofiber using methods described in the relevant literature [52,53]. After spin-coating a nanofiber suspension onto Au/Ti electrodes, we confirmed that an individual fibre had bridged the electrode gap (500 nm) using FE-SEM. We then obtained the intrinsic resistivity of an individual nanofiber from a linear current-voltage relation up to 1 V. As shown in Figure 7(b) [49], the electrical resistivity at room temperature of the individual as-grown carbon nanofiber was extremely high (ca. 280 kΩ) compared with an arc-based multi-walled carbon nanotube (ca. 2.4 kΩ) [54]. This result can be explained by the peculiar platelet-like morphology of the nanofibers investigated in the present study: the current flow between graphene layers in graphite (along the fiber length direction) is six times lower than that in the graphene plane (a-axis) [55]. Although no general relationship between thermal treatment temperature and the electrical resistivity of an individual fibre was observed (possibly due to the inhomogeneous diameter distribution), the substituted B atoms in the carbon nanofibers lowered the Fermi level, thus improving the electrical conductivity of the carbon nanofibers. The effectiveness of the B-doped carbon nanofibers was examined as an anode material for high-rate LIBs. We have demonstrated that the substituted B atoms improve electrical conductivity as well as give rise to multi-loop formation, producing an outer surface that is stable (or inert) against electrolytes. Figure 8(a) and (b) shows the voltage profiles of the second discharging/charging cycle for carbon nanofibers prepared under different conditions [49]. The increased proportion of the lithium discharge/charge plateau below 0.2 V with increasing thermal treatment temperature (Figure 8a) and B doping (Figure 8b) indicates that Li+ insertion/desertion was the main mechanism and that structural integrity was improved. The large amount of Li+ adsorption onto B-substituted planar carbon materials has been theoretically confirmed by molecular orbital calculations [56]; this improved Li+ adsorption is one reason for the improved discharge capacity of the B-doped carbon nanofibers, since B atoms act as an electron acceptor and induce redistribution of the π-electrons within loops. In addition, we found that the capacity of the B-doped carbon nanofibers degraded to a lesser extent at high-discharge current density (Figure 8c and d) than that of the undoped samples. In other words, substituted B atoms within carbon nanofibers enhanced the electrical conductivity of individual carbon nanofibers as well as formed loop-ended surfaces that were stable (or inert) against electrolytes. The active end planes in platelet-type carbon nanofiber are structurally converted to stable multi-loops at lower temperature by addition of B atoms. The most reactive end planes are the first to react with the B atoms, thus leading to incorporation of B into the loops. It is thought that the end sites of the end planes are saturated by hydrogen, as oxygen containing functional groups are effectively removed by thermal treatment above 1000 °C in argon. Upon thermal treatment at high temperatures in the presence of B, the C–H bond is broken, which induces the formation of a B–C bond. Eventually, the adjacent end planes containing B atoms will covalently connect to adjacent parallel graphene layers and increase the density of multi-loops on the outer surface of the carbon nanofiber. The highly intensified D band and wide HWHM of the G band were experimental evidence for the substitution of B atoms into multi-loops. As a result, B-doped carbon nanofibers exhibited improved electrical conductivity, higher crystallinity and more stable (or inert) surfaces, which are expected to make them useful as the anode material for high-rate LIBs. 6. Edge-enriched porous carbons for supercapacitors with high volumetric capacitance Supercapacitors can store and deliver energy via a simple charge separation [57], and thus they have attracted attention for a variety of applications as hybrid systems with battery, internal combustion engine, and fuel cell, due to their high peak power and rapid response to external loading on a powertrain [58,59]. Characteristics on power performance of the supercapacitors are highly essential to improve the rate performance of batteries and for decreasing the CO2 emission from the internal combustion engine. Thus, many efforts to develop electrode materials using various types and forms of carbons (i.e., activated carbons, mesoporous carbons, carbide-derived carbons, carbon nanotubes and graphenes) for high-performance supercapacitors have been made [60–76]. However, the reported results are still insufficient for practical applications, especially, from the viewpoint of cost and simplicity on the manufacturing of the host materials. Furthermore, the specific capacitance per unit volume (Wh/L) is of prime importance for practical applications to vehicles due to their restricted space. The volumetric capacitance is closely related to the inherent properties of electrode materials such as the apparent density, active surface area that practically contributes to capacitance uptake, pore size, and ionic accessibility. However, the past major researches on capacitor/condenser have concerned the specific energy (Wh/kg), and then many researchers have been interested in the materials with high specific surface area (SSA) with a limited consideration of the efficiency of capacitance uptake. Microporous carbons, with predominant edge sites, were demonstrated to show the best electrode material of high energy density supercapacitors [77]. More specifically, potassium hydroxides-activated porous mesophase pitch carbon fibers showed the best electrochemical performance as electrode for supercapacitor as an auxiliary power supply for the hybrid type fuel cell vehicles [78]. As a reference sample, highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) was chemically activated by using KOH to envisage the KOH effect on a graphitic basal plane. Direct observations by SEM (Figure 9a and 9b ) provide a clue for understanding the reactivity of KOH against graphitic basal plane [78]. By comparison of the KOH-activated HOPG with the non-treated one, the morphological change is clearly observed. The reaction by molten KOH forms many pits and cracks on the basal plane of HOPG due to different kinetic route via consideration of three-phase reactions on activation procedure. These pits, formed by the attack of molten KOH, have various depths and diameters. The pit diameter becomes smaller as the depth increases because of the progress of the KOH erosion. Therefore, the inside of the pit has a certain amount of inclination. Edge planes with graphitic hexagonal lattice were exposed on the inclination of pit. These topological variations on the basal plane are clearly observed also in the STM images. Consequently, novel mechanism of the KOH activation of HOPG is demonstrated by microscopic evidences for the evolution of pits on the basal plane and pore creation in atomic scale. Mesophase pitch carbon fibers (MPCFs) were previously annealed at 650 °C becaue it is expected that the well-ordered layers could be available to expose the prismatic planes produced by KOH attack. The activated MPCFs have typical microporous nature with predominant distribution of pore size in the range of 0.7 to 1.1 nm. The HR-TEM observations revealed that carbon skeletons with densely entangled graphene network structure were lost after KOH activation for MPCF-650 (Figure 10a and 10b ) [78]. It can be explained by presence of the inter-graphene layer-gaps which correspond to intermolecular dimensions and thus can be interpreted as micropores. Considering the activated sample, the networks consisting of graphene layers become sparser, owing to etching by KOH. The 3-D image facilitates understanding of structural variation induced by the collapse of graphene network. Changes of in-plane size of graphene layer (L a) and lattice structure with activation were confirmed using Raman spectroscopy (Figure 10c and 10d) [78]. After the activation, the D band around 1350 cm−1 slightly shifts to lower frequency and its intensity increases remarkably. From the relative ratio (R = I D/I G), we are able to evaluate the change in the in-plane crystallite size after the KOH-activation using the following empirical equation. Such a large decrease in the in-plane size of the KOH-activated MPCFs could be explained by the drilling behaviors of the molten KOH on the well-developed graphene layers that are aligned along the fiber length direction. Figure 11 shows the specific capacitances per unit weight, volume, and SSA for the single electrodes of ac-MPCFs and commercialized conventional ACs [78]. For conventional AC electrodes, specific capacitance per weight increases with increasing the SSA. However, the capacitances obtained from the ac-MPCF electrodes greatly deviate from the general tendency of capacitances obtained from the AC ones. Although the ac-MPCFs have the SSA near 1000 m2/g (i.e., 730∼1274 m2/g), they show extremely high capacitance corresponding to those for conventional AC materials with SSA of 3000 m2/g. The merits on our novel electrode materials become clear for the volumetric capacitance. The ac-MPCF electrode with the SSA of 730 m2/g shows dramatically high volumetric capacitance of nearly 160 F/cc. Furthermore, average volumetric capacitance of ac-MPCF electrodes is 2–3 times higher than that of conventional AC electrodes. As to the capacitance per unit SSA, the maximum value of the capacitance per unit SSA was obtained at SSA of 1700 m2/g for the conventional AC electrodes. The capacitances per unit SSA for ac-MPCF electrodes, which imply accessibility of solvated ion into pores, increase with decreasing the SSA. Such an anomalous behavior is ascribed to the predominant microporosity that can maximize the density of ion storage, and the contribution of the exposed edge planes that have high ability to accumulate more charges than the basal planes. These two factors are required to design the supercapacitor with high volumetric capacitance. The high-performance originates from novel activation mechanism of MPCF with KOH (Figure 11d) [78]. Molten KOH attacks perpendicular to the basal planes, resulting in formation of a pit, and then it continues to penetrate in depth. During the penetration process of KOH, the residual molten KOH on the pore wall allows further penetration through fissure-like defects between the graphene crystallites, which can create more defects that act as a micropore. Finally, developed porous structure with edge plane dominated pore walls can be obtained. In conclusion, enriched edges can give two desirable effects on the performances of supercapacitor. Firstly, the edge can function as an entrance for an ion access into intraparticle pore formed between the graphene layers. Secondly, the contribution of edge plane to capacitance is larger than that of basal plane; the efficient utilization of the edge planes can be considered as a critical factor to govern the capacitor performance. 7. Cup-stacked carbon nanotubes with edge planes as Pt support for fuel cell For a decade, nanocarbon materials have been widely studied as catalyst supports in heterogeneous catalysis due to their unique morphology and reactivity [79–81]. It is well known that the basic properties of impregnated catalyst are strongly affected by impregnation method, the microstructure, the surface reactivity and the metal precursor, [81,82]. Among these factors, the morphology and nanostructure of supporting carbon materials are considered to be main factor in order to obtain high dispersion of nanoparticle catalyst. The efficient impregnation of Pt nanoparticles (diameter = ca. 3 nm) on cup-stacked carbon nanotubes is reported [83]. The cup-stacked carbon nanotubes showed a stacking morphology of truncated conical graphene layers and thus they exhibited a large fraction of active edges on the outer surface and also in the hollow core. The method involves the dispersion of the cup-stacked carbon nanotubes in H2PtCl6, followed by low temperature annealing. The Pt particle deposition was homogeneous, and could be controlled selectively on the outer or internal core (Figure 12 ). The homogneous impregnation of Pt nanoparticles in the hollow core and/or on the outer surface of cup-stacked carbon nanotubes was caused by a strong interaction between metal salt and the active edge sites. Since the Pt particle activity on the surface of cup-stacked carbon nanotubes was found to be high [84], this material could find applications as efficient catalysts in fuel cell. 8. Conclusions Graphite consists of two different sites: the homogeneous smooth basal plane and the chemically and electrochemically active edges. Thus, controlling the number of edges relative to basal planes is critical for maximizing the electrochemical performance of carbon-based energy storage devices. When the size of carbon materials becomes smaller, the concentration of edges can be extremely high compared with the surface area of basal planes. Thus, the contribution of edges to the physical, chemical, and electronic properties of nanoscale carbon materials will be more dominant. Even though the role of the edges in carbon materials has been intensively investigated for the last 10 years, their full potential is largely limited because of the following reasons: (1) the edge configuration changes continuously by chemical functionalization, (2) there are limited characterization tools for quantitatively evaluating the ratio of edges to basal planes, and (3) there is no experimental method for creating a specific type of clean and stable edge in a controllable fashion. However, when considering the tremendous scientific and industrial push for the utilization of nanocarbon materials in energy storage devices, the hidden role of the edges will be uncovered soon with the help of nanoscience and nanotechnology. Kim M Ezaka K Osada T Yanagisawa T Hayashi M Terrones MS Dresselhaus Nano Lett 3 2003 723 84 C Kim YJ Kim YA Kim T Yanagisawa M Endo MS Dresselhaus J Appl Phys 96 2004 5903 Yoong Ahm Kim received his PhD in Material Engineering from Shinshu University, Japan in 2001. He is an associate professor of Shinshu University and has published about 175 papers in international journals. His current research areas are carbon nanotube-based transparent conductive film, optical properties of double walled carbon nanotubes, fabrication of novel nanofibers by electrospinning, biological compatibility of carbon nanotubes, fabrication of high quality graphene, application of nanocarbons in energy storage devices, and nanocarbon-based 3D scaffold for growing cells. Takuya Hayashi received his PhD in 1999 from University of Tokyo, Japan. He is a professor of Shinshu University and has published about 175 papers in international journals. His research interests are structural analysis and property measurements of carbon nanomaterials using high resolution transmission electron microscopy, in-situ physical property measurement of nanostructured carbon materials and simulation of carbon nanomaterial formation, and its property prediction. Jin Hee Kim received her PhD in the Bioscience and Textile Technology from Shinshu University, Japan in 2012. She is a researcher of Carbon Institute of Science and Technology of Shinshu University and has published about 18 papers in international journals. Her research interests are dispersion and separation of single or double walled carbon nanotubes using DNA, DNA-dispersed carbon nanotube-based transparent conductive film, electrospinning of mussel protein and DNA in a form of nan of iber web, mussel protein/carbon nanotube-derived electrospun tissue scaffold for growing cell and porous DNA/nanotube composite for removing toxic dioxin. Morinobu Endo studied electrical and engineering at Shinshu University, Japan and obtained his PhD from the University of Orleans, France in 1975. It is in his PhD work that he had developed the synthesis method of carbon nanotubes, and showed that it is a tubular structure for the first time. He is a COE of Institute of Carbon Science and Technology and a distinguished professor of Research Centre for Exotic Nanocarbons in Shinshu University and his current interests are science and technology of nanocarbons such as carbon nanotubes, and the development of high-performance energy storage devices (e.g., lithium ion battery, electric double-layer capacitor).

coredata.dc:description: Nanostructured carbon materials, including carbon nanotubes, graphene and nanoporous carbon, show promise for expanding renewable energy. In particular, the configuration and electronic properties of graphene edges in relation with their electrochemical activity have become a major issue in carbon-based energy storage devices. Here, we review recent results concerning the important roles of graphene edges as the gateway for lithium ion intercalation in the anode of lithium-ion batteries, as promoters of high capacitance in carbon-based supercapacitors, and as anchoring sites for Pt nanoparticles in fuel cells. We envisage that the controlled synthesis of a specific, clean, and stable edge configuration could be achieved to maximize the electrochemical performance of nanostructured carbon-based energy storage devices.
